Q. Why do bubbles in a glass of Champagne start at the bottom?

A. ''Gas bubbles that form in a liquid, including water vapor bubbles that form as water boils, need a tiny flaw or inhomogeneity to seed them,'' said Dr. Eberhard Bodenschatz, professor of physics at Cornell. A baby bubble then adds other pockets of gas and grows, and once it has expanded to a certain size, it tears off and starts to rise.

The necessary flaws are found on the surface of the glass of champagne, Dr. Bodenschatz said. Carbon dioxide bubbles form at preferred spots and rise up in a line from it. Those that originate at the bottom of a Champagne flute are obvious because they rise in the middle. Others may form at the sides and slide up unnoticed because of the steep shape of the glass, he suggested.
The bubble inception process is called nucleation, Dr. Bodenschatz said, and the formation of the tiny pressure depression that lets it happen is called cavitation.

Surface tension on the surface of the bubble forms a barrier to bubble growth. ''It is very hard to cavitate a pure fluid because you need a little void to start the bubble,'' Dr. Bodenschatz said. ''It takes a bubble to make a bubble.''
Once the void forms, scientists can calculate how fast a bubble will grow based on pressure and tension.
To boil a liquid without an explosive effusion of the liquid, chemists use a rough-surfaced object, a boiling stone, to encourage cavitation.
